# Java Fundamentals

<span class="lead"> </span>

The fundamentals of Java are discussed during these modules. Specific emphasis is placed on Java constructs needed for Web API programming with the Spring Framework. Topics include:

-   Using the Standard JDK
-   OOP
-   Java Types
-   Java Classes
-   Interfaces
-   Abstract Classes
-   Lambda Expressions
-   Using GitHub with Java
-   Use JetBrains IntelliJ IDEA IDE
-   Dependency Injection
-   SQL
-   RDBMS
-   Query Single Table
-   Query Multiple Table
-   PostgreSQL
-   REST API
-   Maven, Spring, Tomcat

## [Java - JDK and Java Classes](../module/recAGVTYNZyJbEFpu)

<span id="The_Java_Development_Kit"></span>

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to understand what makes Java a programming language worth studying
-   Student should be able to explain the basic concept of Object Oriented Programming and how they relate to Java
-   Student should be able to create and manipulate the base Java types which include Boolean, byte, char (including Strings), short, int, long, float, and double
-   Student should be able to craft multiple Java Classes which include comments, constructors, static and instance variables (fields), accessors, public and private methods and instantiate and use Objects of these classes.
-   Student should be able to implement and use the String and Date data types
-   Student should be able to understand the reason behind and use of BigDecimals (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and use for loops (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and use while loops and do while loops (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and use recursion (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and use Java conditionals, branching, including if-then, if-then-else, and switch statements (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)

## [Java Interfaces, Abstract Classes, Lambda Expression](../module/rec6Hrk77HupYeoN5)

<span id="Interfaces_Abstract_Classes_Lambda_Expressions"></span>

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to craft and manipulate Collections
-   Student should be able to craft and manipulate ArrayList Collections
-   Student should be able to use and implement interfaces
-   Student should be able to use and implement abstract classes
-   Student should be able to use and implement Lambda Expressions
-   Student should be able to craft and manipulate Arrays Collections (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and manipulate HashMap Collections (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to craft and manipulate HashSet Collections (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)

## [Java - RDBMS and SQL Basics](../module/recyJ663TrxVgpqY9)

<span id="RDBMS_and_SQL"></span>

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to explain what a Relational Database is and its core components
-   Student should be able to explain what SQL is and its advantages over other RDBMS
-   Student should be able to query data from a single table
-   Student should be able to query multiple tables data
-   Student should be able to perform CRUD operations on an RDBMS using SQL
-   Student should be able to open an existing database, or create a new one, while adding tables to a PostgreSQL database
-   Student should be able to explain data normalization and normal forms while normalizing data to the 3rd Normal Form (3NF)

## [Java - Intro to Maven, Spring, and Tomcat Using REST API](../module/recqtftA9E98qpbak)

<span id="IntelliJ_and_REST_API"></span>

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to use IntelliJ in the following areas: application creation, code entry, and code execution
-   Student should be able to download, commit and branch source control repositories
-   Student should be able to explain the uses of and differences between Maven, Spring, and Tomcat
-   Student should be able to build a REST service using Spring Boot
-   Student should be able to use and implement inversion of control and dependency injection with Spring
-   Student should be able to implement Beans throughout the Beans’ lifecycle controlling the Beans using annotations
-   Student should be able to produce a complete application following the Maven Phases
-   Student should be able to use Postman to manually test Web APIs
-   Student should be able to create Spring Boot Applications with IntelliJ Community Edition (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
-   Student should be able to use tips and tricks of IntelliJ to improve programming efficiency (\*\*\* OPTIONAL \*\*\*)
